# Fondemental Postulates (Axions) of Quantum Mechanics

## State Postulates
state vector $\ket{\psi} \in \mathcal{H}$, $\bra{\psi}\in \mathcal{H}^*$, $\mathcal{H}$ is Hilbert space.
$(\bra{\psi})^\dagger = \ket{\psi}$, $(\ket{\psi})^\dagger = \bra{\psi}$. $\dagger$ is adjoint/Hermitian conjugate.$\dagger$: Transpose + Complex conjugate.

## Oprator Postulates
Physical quantities $\leftrightarrow$ Obeservables $\leftrightarrow$ Operator $\hat{A}$(linear Hermitian).

## Measurement Postulates
1. Measurement Outcome: $\hat{A}\ket{u_n}=A_n\ket{u_n}$.$A_n$ is eigenvalue, $\ket{u_n}$ is eigenstate $.
2. pabability of $A_n$ in $\ket{\psi}$: $P(A_n)=|\braket{u_n|\psi}|^2$. $\ket{\psi}=\sum_n c_n\ket{u_n}$, $c_n=\braket{u_n|\psi}$.
3. State collapse: After measurement, the state is $\ket{u_n}$.

## Dynamics Postulates
Schrodinger Equation: $\i\hbar\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\ket{\psi}=\hat{H}\ket{\psi}$

## Identical Particles Postulates

# State Vector 
## Vector additon
$ \ket{\psi_1}+\ket{\psi_2}=\ket{\psi_2}+\ket{\psi_1} \in \mathcal{H}$
## Scalar multiplication
$a(\ket{\psi_1}+\ket{\psi_2})=a\ket{\psi_1}+a\ket{\psi_2}$
$(a+b)\ket{\psi}=a\ket{\psi}+b\ket{\psi}$
$a,b\in \mathbb{C}$
## Inner product
$\braket{\psi|\phi}=c \in \mathbb{C}$
$\braket{\psi|\phi}=\braket{\phi|\psi}^*$
$\braket{\psi|\psi}=r \in \mathbb{R} \geq 0 ,\text{especially iff} \ket{\psi}=0$
## Dyadic product
$(\ket{\psi}\bra{\phi})^\dagger = \ket{\phi}\bra{\psi}$

# Operator 
$\hat{A}\ket{\psi}=\ket{\phi}$
Two kinds of operators in  QM.
1. Obeservable: linear, hermitian
   $\hat{H}^\dagger=\hat{H}$
2. Transformation: Restrict to linear and unitary transformation
   $\hat{U}^\dagger\hat{U}=\hat{U}\hat{U}^\dagger=\mathbb{1}$
Linearity: $\hat{L}(a\ket{\psi}+b\ket{\phi})=a\hat{L}\ket{\psi}+b\hat{L}\ket{\phi}$

## Adjoint
$\forall \ket{\psi}, \hat{A}\ket{\psi}=\hat{B}\ket{\psi} \Rightarrow \hat{A}=\hat{B}$
$(\hat{A}\hat{B})\ket{\psi}=\hat{A}(\hat{B}\ket{\psi})$
Define Commutator $[\hat{A},\hat{B}]=\hat{A}\hat{B}-\hat{B}\hat{A}$

## Properties of Commutator
$[\hat{A},\hat{B}]= - [\hat{B},\hat{A}]$
$[\hat{A},hat{B+C}]=[\hat{A},\hat{B}]+[\hat{A},\hat{C}]$
$[a\hat{A},b\hat{B}+c\hat{C}]=ab[\hat{A},\hat{B}]+ac[\hat{A},\hat{C}]$
$[\hat{A},\hat{B}\hat{C}]=[\hat{A},\hat{B}]\hat{C}+\hat{B}[\hat{A},\hat{C}]$
$[\hat{A}\hat{B},\hat{C}]=[\hat{A},\hat{C}]\hat{B}+\hat{A}[\hat{B},\hat{C}]$
$[\hat{A},\hat{B}^n]=n[\hat{A},\hat{B}]\hat{B}^{n-1},\big([\hat{A},[\hat{A},\hat{B}]]=0\big)$
$[\hat{A},f(\hat{B})=[\hat{A},\hat{B}]\frac{\partial f}{\partial \hat{{B}}}$
$[\hat{A},[\hat{B},\hat{C}]+[\hat{C},[\hat{A},\hat{B}]+[\hat{B},[\hat{C},\hat{A}]]=0$

## Adjoint (Hermitian Conjugate)
$$ \big(\hat{A}\ket{\psi}\big)^\dagger = \bra{\psi}\hat{A}^\dagger $$
$$ \bra{\psi}\hat{A}^\dagger\ket{\phi} = \braket{\phi|\hat{A}|\psi}^* $$

# Gauge(Transform) Invariance

$$
\left\{ \begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{A}'&=\boldsymbol{A}+\nabla\chi\\
\phi'&=\phi-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\chi}{\partial t}
\end{aligned} \right.
$$
$$
 \begin{aligned}
  \boldsymbol{E}'&=-\nabla\phi'-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\boldsymbol{A}'}{\partial t} \\
  &=-\nabla\bigg(\phi-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\chi}{\partial t}\bigg)-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial}{\partial t}(\boldsymbol{A}+\nabla\chi)\\
  &=-\nabla\phi+\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\chi}{\partial t}-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\boldsymbol{A}}{\partial t}-\nabla\bigg(\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\chi}{\partial t}\bigg)\\
    &=-\nabla\phi-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\boldsymbol{A}}{\partial t}\\
    &=\boldsymbol{E}
\end{aligned}
$$
After the gauge transformation, the electric field remains the same.
$$
\boldsymbol{B}'=\nabla\times(\boldsymbol{A}+\nabla\chi)=\nabla\times\boldsymbol{A}=\boldsymbol{B}
$$
The magnetic field remains the same after the gauge transformation.

## Gauge: Coloumb Gauge
$$ \nabla\cdot\boldsymbol{A}=0 $$
and $ \phi=0 $,call radiation gauge.

## Gauge: Lorenz Gauge
$$ \nabla\cdot\boldsymbol{A}+\frac{1}{c^2}\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial t}=0 $$

# Multipole Expansion
$$ W_e=-\boldsymbol{d}\cdot\boldsymbol{E}$$
d is the eletric-dipole moment.
 $$\boldsymbol{d}=q\boldsymbol{x}$$
$$ W_m=-\boldsymbol{\mu}\cdot\boldsymbol{B}$$
$$\boldsymbol{\mu}=\frac{q\boldsymbol{L}}{2mc}$$

# Canonical Quantization
a) Viraable: cannonical
position $\boldsymbol{x}$, momentum $\boldsymbol{p}$
$$A(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{p})\to\hat{A}(\hat{x},\hat{q}) $$
b) Commutation relation
CM:

$$
\begin{align}
    [x_i,p_j]_{PB}&=\delta_{ij} \\
    [x_i,x_j]_{PB}&=[p_i,p_j]_{PB}=0  
\end{align}
$$
QM:
$$
\begin{align}
    [\hat{x}_i,\hat{p}_j]&=\i\hbar\delta_{ij} \\
    [\hat{x}_i,\hat{x}_j]&=[\hat{p}_i,\hat{p}_j]=0
\end{align}
$$

# Properties of $\boldsymbol{e}_{i,j,k}$
1. Othonomality
$$ \boldsymbol{e}_i\cdot\boldsymbol{e}_j=\delta_{ij} $$
2. Completeness
$$ \sum_{i=1}^{3}\boldsymbol{e}_i\boldsymbol{e}_i=\mathbb{1}\quad(\text{并矢}) $$

# Vector Analysis
Use Enstein  Convention.
$\vec{x}= x_i\vec{e}_i$
inner product
$$\vec{e}_i\cdot\vec{e}_j=\delta_{ij}\quad (i,j=1,2,3)$$
$\delta_{ij}$ is Kronecker Delta.
cross product
$$\vec{e}_i\times\vec{e}_j=\epsilon_{ijk}\vec{e}_k \quad (i,j,k=1,2,3)$$
$\epsilon_{ijk}$ is Levi-Civita Symbol.

## Properties of $\delta_{ij}$ & $\epsilon_{ijk}$
Symmetry and Anti-symmetry.
$$
\delta_{ij}=\delta_{ji}
$$
$$
\epsilon_{ijk}=-\epsilon_{jik}
$$

Defination of $\delta_{ij}$ & $\epsilon_{ijk}$
$$
\delta_{ij}=
\begin{cases}
1 & i=j \\
0 & i\neq j
\end{cases}
$$
Orhtogonormality.

$$
\epsilon_{ijk}=
\begin{cases}
1 &   \text{even permutation}  \\
-1 &   \text{odd permutation}  \\
0 & \text{no permutation}
\end{cases}
$$

if $F_{ij}=F{ji}$, then $\epsilon_{ijk}F_{ij}\equiv 0$
$$
F_i\delta_{ij}=F_j
$$

## Vector Algebra
$\forall \vec{A},\vec{B}$, $\vec{A}=A_i\vec{e}_i$, $\vec{B}=B_i\vec{e}_i$
$$
\begin{align}
\vec{A}\cdot\vec{B} &= (A_i\vec{e}_i)\cdot(B_j\vec{e}_j) \\
&= (A_iB_j)(\vec{e}_i\cdot\vec{e}_j) \\
&= A_iB_i\delta_{ij} \\
&= A_iB_i
\end{align}
$$

$$
\begin{align}
\vec{A}\times\vec{B} &= (A_i\vec{e}_i)\times(B_j\vec{e}_j) \\
&= (A_iB_j)(\vec{e}_i\times\vec{e}_j) \\
&= A_iB_i\epsilon_{ijk}\vec{e}_k \\
&= \vec{e}_k(A_iB_i\epsilon_{kij}) \\
&= \vec{e}_k(\vec{A}\times\vec{B})_k 
\end{align}
$$

$$
\boxed{
(\vec{A}\times\vec{B})_i = \epsilon_{ijk}A_jB_k
}
$$

$$
\epsilon_{ijk}= \vec{e}_i\cdot(\vec{e}_j\times\vec{e}_k)
$$

$$
\epsilon_{ijk}\epsilon_{lmn}=
\begin{vmatrix}
\delta_{il} & \delta_{im} & \delta_{in} \\
\delta_{jl} & \delta_{jm} & \delta_{jn} \\
\delta_{kl} & \delta_{km} & \delta_{kn} \\
\end{vmatrix}
$$

$$
\boxed{\epsilon_{ijk}\epsilon_{klm}= \delta_{il}\delta_{jm}-\delta_{im}\delta_{jl}}
$$

$$
\vec{a}\cdot(\vec{b}\times\vec{c})=\vec{b}\cdot(\vec{c}\times\vec{a})=\vec{c}\cdot(\vec{a}\times\vec{b})
$$
### important formula
$$
\nabla(uv)=u\nabla v+v\nabla u
$$
$$ \nabla\times(\nabla\times\vec{A)})=\nabla(\nabla\cdot\vec{A})-\nabla^2\vec{A}$$
$$ \nabla\cdot(\nabla\times\phi)\equiv0$$
$$ \nabla\times(\nabla\vec{A})\equiv0$$
$$ \nabla^2\bigg(\frac{1}{r}\bigg)=4\pi\delta(\vec{r})$$
$$ \nabla\bigg(\frac{1}{r}\bigg)=-\frac{\vec{r}}{r^3}$$

### Generalized Stokes Theorem

$$
\int_{\partial\Omega} \omega = \int_{\Omega} \d\omega
$$
1. Newton-Leibniz Formula
$$
\int_{a}^{b} f'(x)\d x = \int_{a}^{b} \d f(x) = f(b)-f(a)
$$
2. Green's Theorem
$$
\oint f\d x+g\d y = \iint\limits_{D} \bigg(\frac{\partial g}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\bigg)\d x\d y
$$
3. Gauss-Ostrogradsky Theorem
$$
\oiint_\Sigma \vec{F}\cdot\d\vec{\Sigma} = \int_V \nabla\cdot\vec{F}\d V
$$
$$
\oiint_\Sigma \psi\d\vec{\Sigma} = \int_V \nabla\psi\d V
$$
$$
\oiint_\Sigma \d\vec{\Sigma}\times\vec{A} = \int_V \Big(\nabla\times\vec{A}\Big)\d V
$$
4. Kelvin-Stokes Theorem
$$
\oint_L \vec{F}\cdot\d\vec{l} = \iint\limits_{\Sigma} \Big(\nabla\times\vec{F}\Big)\cdot\d\vec{\Sigma}
$$

### Helmholtz Theorem
$\forall \vec{F}$,contitinuous and differentiable,
$$
\vec{F}=\vec{F}_\parallel+\vec{F}_\perp
$$
$$
\left\{\begin{align}
\nabla\times\vec{F}_\parallel &\equiv 0 \\
\nabla\cdot\vec{F}_\perp &\equiv 0
\end{align}\right.
$$
$$
\cases{
\vec{F}_\parallel = -\nabla\phi \\
\vec{F}_\perp = \nabla\times\vec{A}
}
$$

# Experimental laws
## Coulomb's Law
$$
\begin{align}
\boldsymbol{E}(\boldsymbol{r})&=\int\frac{\rho(\boldsymbol{r'})}{|\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r'}|^3}(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r'})\d^3 \boldsymbol{r'}\\
&=-\nabla\phi
\end{align}
$$
$$\nabla\cdot\boldsymbol{E}=4\pi\rho(\boldsymbol{r})$$
## Biot-Savart's Law
$$
\begin{align}
\boldsymbol{B}(\boldsymbol{r})&=\frac{1}{c}\int\frac{\boldsymbol{J}(\boldsymbol{r'})\times(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r'})}{|\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r'}|^3}\d^3 \boldsymbol{r'}\\
&=\nabla\times\boldsymbol{A}
\end{align}
$$
$$\nabla\cdot\boldsymbol{B}=0$$

## Ampere's Law (Circuit)
$$
\oint\boldsymbol{B}\cdot\d\boldsymbol{l}=\frac{4\pi}{c}\iint_{\Sigma}\boldsymbol{J}\cdot\d\boldsymbol{\Sigma}
$$
$$\nabla\times\boldsymbol{B}=\frac{4\pi}{c}\boldsymbol{J}+\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\boldsymbol{E}}{\partial t}$$

## Faraday's Law (Induction)
$$
\oint\boldsymbol{E}\cdot\d\boldsymbol{l}=-\frac{1}{c}\iint_{\Sigma}\frac{\partial\boldsymbol{B}}{\partial t}\cdot\d\boldsymbol{\Sigma}
$$
$$
\nabla\times\boldsymbol{E}=-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\boldsymbol{B}}{\partial t}
$$

## Continuity law of eletric charge
$
\frac{\d Q}{\d t}=0
$ , $ Q=\int_{V}\rho(\boldsymbol{r},t)\d^3\boldsymbol{r}$
$$
\Rightarrow \nabla\cdot\boldsymbol{J}+\frac{\partial\rho}{\partial t}=0
$$

## Maxwell's Equation
$$
\left\{\begin{align}
\nabla\cdot\boldsymbol{E}&=4\pi\rho \\
\nabla\cdot\boldsymbol{B}&=0 \\
\nabla\times\boldsymbol{E}&=-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\boldsymbol{B}}{\partial t} \\
\nabla\times\boldsymbol{B}&=\frac{4\pi}{c}\boldsymbol{J}+\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\boldsymbol{E}}{\partial t}
\end{align}\right.
$$

## Lorentz Force
$$
\boldsymbol{F}=q(\boldsymbol{E}+\boldsymbol{v}/c\times\boldsymbol{B})
$$

# 量子力学笔记-经典力学(I)
## Lagerange Mechanics
Lagrange's Equation
$$\delta S=0 \Rightarrow \frac{d}{dt}(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_a})=\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_a}$$
L is Lagragian.
$$L=L(q(t),\dot{q}(t),t)$$
S is Action(作用量).
$$ S = \int_{t_1}^{t_2} L(q(t),\dot{q}(t),t)dt=S[q]$$
$q(t)$ is generalized coordinate(广义坐标), $\dot{q}(t)$ is generalized velocity(广义速度),$\dot{q}$ is in condfiguration space.

## Hamilton Mechanics
Hamitonian mechanics is in phase space.$(q(t),p(t))$ is in phase space,call it canonical coordinate.
$$L=L(q(t),\dot{q}(t),t)\stackrel{p=\frac{\partial{L}}{\partial{\dot{q}}}}{\longrightarrow} H=H(q(t),p(t),t)$$

Hamilton's Equation
$$
\begin{cases}
\dot{q_a} = \frac{\partial H}{\partial p} \\
\dot{p_a} = -\frac{\partial H}{\partial q}
\end{cases}
$$
$a = 1,2,\cdots,D$
Genelized hamioltonian equation
$$\forall f(q,p,t) \Rightarrow \frac{df}{dt}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial t}+[f,H]_{PB}$$
where $[f,H]_{PB}=\sum(\frac{\partial f}{\partial q_a}\frac{\partial H}{\partial p_a}-\frac{\partial f}{\partial p_a}\frac{\partial H}{\partial q_a})$ is Poisson Bracket/Classical Canonical Commutation.
Two fimilar equation in QC, Henseberg Equation and Erenfest Theorem.
$$\frac{d\hat{f}}{dt}=\frac{\partial \hat{f}}{\partial t}+\frac{1}{\i\hbar}[\hat{f},\hat{H}]$$
$$\frac{d}{dt}\langle f \rangle = \langle \frac{\partial f}{\partial t} \rangle + \frac{1}{\i\hbar}\langle [f,H] \rangle$$
Canonical Equation of motion
$$
\cases{
    \dot{q_a}= [q_a,H]_{PB} \\
    \dot{p_a}=  [p_a,H]_{PB}
}
$$
Canonical Transformation
$$ H(q,p,t)\rightarrow K(Q,P,t)$$
$$
\cases{
    [q_i,p_i]_{PB} = \delta_{ij} \\
    [q_i,q_j]=[p_i,p_j]_{PB} = 0 \\
}
$$
$$ ([Q_i,P_i]_{PB})_{QP}=([Q_i,P_i]_{PB})_{qp}$$
